captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Well, it&#39;s different. At least it&#39;s not called. 
&quot;Vengeance Rising: Aftermath&quot; or whatever. I don&#39;t

know if it&#39;s an improvement. &quot;V Rising&quot; sounds 
more like ER doctor shorthand for some malady

of the female reproductive organs. In truth, V 
Rising is a base-building crafting action RPG

sort of affair, but rather than being the usual 
hapless shlub in leaf pants going about smacking

trees and rocks, you&#39;re a cool and dangerous 
vampire warrior going about smacking trees and

rocks. I like the way our character continues 
doing their cool swishy attack combos with cape

fluttering dramatically as they cut down trees. 
Nice commitment to the bit. V Rising employs

an overhead camera, giving the action RPG bits a 
sort of Diablo-y feel and the base building bits

an aura of The Sims, the whole effect being akin 
to an updated version of the first Legacy of Kain

game but where Kain splits his time equally 
between bloody revenge upon the living and

landscape gardening. The story of Elevated Vagina 
is, to put it diplomatically, clearly geared for

the attention deficit. One cutscene at the start 
and that&#39;s your lot. &quot;Hey, vampires used to rule,

now they drool, humans run the world now, you&#39;re 
a vampire, do something about it I guess.&quot;

Then you wake up in a cemetery with nothing 
but your dad&#39;s old trousers and a crafting

recipe for a pointy stick. Feel like adding a 
bit more context to this, game? &quot;Piss off and

punch some trees, bitch, I&#39;m not Anne fucking 
Rice.&quot; Not that the game is without direction,

the various mechanics are dribbled in 
through a series of mandatory quests,

craft pointy stick, beat wolf to death, clean 
fragments of wolf skull off your tights,

christ you&#39;re a natural. We&#39;re thankfully 
spared having to scarf down water and wolf

guts to keep hunger and thirst meters topped 
up, but as a vampire we do need to drink blood,

which is an interesting curveball. Different blood 
has different qualities but it keeps running out,

you might find a virgin kick boxing instructor 
whose blood gives you 50% extra damage and

regeneration but then you use it all up taking a 
few too many hits and have to scurry home on two

crack addicts and a dead caterpillar. Anyway, 
we get handheld through our first few ventures

into a countryside dotted with bandit camps and 
a startling amount of unclaimed real estate, on

which we construct a base, making do with wooden 
barriers and magical mist generators before we can

start taking refuge from the sun with anything 
as technologically sophisticated as a ceiling.

And once we&#39;re settled the game unveils 
our actual goal, broadly speaking:

we need to gather some V-blood. Ewwww. I didn&#39;t 
realise we were THAT kind of vampire. We using

a cunnilingus-based gathering method or just 
looking for used sanitary products to dip in

hot water like teabags? Not THAT kind of V-blood. 
The V stands for Very Important or something. You

have to hunt down unique boss characters scattered 
across the map because their blood will bestow

upon you sacred knowledge, like how to cast 
certain spells, build smelting plants and trim

the hedges. You just have to make sure you&#39;re 
sufficiently upgraded to take on the bosses,

and that&#39;s determined entirely by gear score, 
which is one of the things that turns me off

tech tree crafty RPGs. In the traditional RPG 
model you at least know that you&#39;re always

gaining XP even if you&#39;ve just spent the last 
three hours slaughtering farmyard cows out of

some vague sense of underlying hostility, but in 
Fanny Flaps Ascending you could systematically

murder the entire population of Wolverhampton 
and make zero fucking progress &#39;cos none of them

dropped the wool thread required to craft your 
next underpants upgrade, so you&#39;ve officially

achieved bugger all besides freeing up some 
seating at the next Wanderers FC home game.

But once you have stitched together some 
competitively rated long johns the boss

fights are probably the highlight 
of the game. How can they not be,

everything else is copy pasted bandit camps 
and picking out your preferred style of

drapes while you wait for the copper to finish 
smelting. The bosses are all unique characters

with flamboyant personalities and voice lines, 
you&#39;d almost think they&#39;d been led to believe

they were in a game with a plot. It&#39;s like 
butchering your way through the entire cast

of a hero shooter. And the combat mainly avoids 
becoming a Diablo-style clickfest of attrition,

it rewards more complex tactics like waiting for 
an opening and getting out of the way of things,

although having said that, a five second cooldown 
on the dodge move is a bit much. What, do you need

to iron your cape between each one? Oh how 
interesting, I cracked the top of this creme

brulee of complaints about V Rising and I&#39;m 
noticing now it&#39;s about three feet deep. Two

spell slots? There&#39;s like nineteen fucking skill 
trees for magic and I can only equip two spells?

So I go to all the trouble of killing a boss and 
all I get is a token to spend on ice magic, which

is a fat lot of good to me when I&#39;m currently 
maining fireball and manifest sexy blancmange.

Gosh, this is a tasty creme brulee. Let&#39;s keep 
going. I got stuck at one point because the

critical path mission was to build and use a 
teleporter. Which felt like a critical step,

a teleporter on base would be handy, much 
better than having to transport your castle

every time you start a new area, and when 
I say &quot;transport&quot; I mean &quot;painstakingly

rebuild grid square by grid square&quot; which 
really felt like the kind of thing a vampire

lord would have an Igor around for. Building the 
teleporter was easy, but when I tried to use it,

the game went &quot;You cannot teleport while carrying 
certain items.&quot; Okay. Well I&#39;m currently carrying

nine kinds of rock, six different plants and 
a fish skeleton, you wanna be more specific?

&quot;Nope. Just hover over everything and we&#39;ll tell 
you what you can&#39;t have.&quot; I ain&#39;t got time for

that much hovering! I&#39;m not a Californian parent! 
Yes y- ALRIGHT TECHNICALLY I AM. I consulted with

colleagues and was informed that I can disable 
teleport restrictions in the world settings,

so I did get around that. Incidentally this 
is a game intended for online multiplayer

but I was stubbornly playing single 
player as always &#39;cos if I wanted to

be bullied by vampire nerds in inexpensive 
leather outfits I&#39;d hang out at the mall.

And as I progressed, the game took a rather 
severe dip in pace in the second act,

when all the recipes start calling for 
iron, which takes fucking forever to smelt,

but the real problem was the aforementioned 
wool thread. I couldn&#39;t manufacture that at all,

my loom refused to because I hadn&#39;t yet found 
tailor&#39;s shop floor to put it on. You prissy

little bitch, loom. Sorry all my floors are a 
touch too heterosexual for your taste. Sorry,

that was uncalled for. So I thought, I know, 
I&#39;ll just buy some thread from the local human

merchants with those quaint little copper discs 
they like so much. I&#39;d done so easily enough in

the previous area, unfortunately the merchants in 
the new area were in the middle of a human town,

and none of them would do business with me &#39;cos 
I&#39;d just murdered all the gate guards right in

front of them. I tried to casually walk in 
with my weapons sheathed &quot;Don&#39;t mind me,

lads, just doing some shopping,&quot; and they all 
just started screaming &quot;VAMPIRE VAMPIRE&quot; and

setting their own town on fire. I did find 
some sheep, but all they dropped was hide,

apparently the connection between sheep and 
wool wasn&#39;t covered in the vampire induction

process. And that&#39;s the point I lost patience 
with V Rising and spent the rest of the week

reviewing my toenail clippers. Two stars, maybe 
two and a half for the emery board attachment.

Hello, I felt like doing another
From the Heart Over the Credits voice,

because I need to
vent about the really sodding

stressful weekend I
had fixing up bugs in my new

game Starstruck
Vagabond. Out now on Steam. I

tell ya, it&#39;s great
that as a solo developed indie
game with a low file size, any bug can be

fixed and the build
updated inside 10 minutes,

but you balance that with not
having the chance to get nearly enough QA done.

Anyway, if you were holding out
pretty much all the major bugs are squashed now,
why not buy it if you like Chill Out Time

Killer Post-Ad
Games with epic sci-fi plots.

And if you want to support me and or
Second Wind, making the content you love,

and you&#39;re allergic
to Patreon or something.
